title: How to Save Space in Your Home

steps.headline: Replace ottoman, coffee tables and benches with models that have interior storage.
steps.description: Storage ottomans and benches often cost approximately the same as less functional versions of the same furniture.

steps.headline: Place bookcases behind the sofa, next to beds and next to furniture.
steps.description: They can double as tables as well as storage.

steps.headline: Turn a hallway into a storage space.
steps.description: Line it with hooks and hang coats, hats or even pots and pans.

steps.headline: Install magnetic strips in the kitchen, office, shop or bedroom.
steps.description: Hang metallic objects like knives, office supplies, tools and jewelry on them.

steps.headline: Hang your bike on the wall to free up your entryway.
steps.description: You can buy a metal wall-mount or a wooden mount that doubles as a bookshelf.

steps.headline: Modify a cabinet to contain a pet bed or litter tray.
steps.description: Remove the door or install a pet door into one side of a bottom cabinet.

steps.headline: Create vertical storage for baking sheets, cooking boards and other long, thin kitchen items.
steps.description: Purchase tension rods and align them vertically in rows of two between shelves. Insert the items between the rods to save drawer space.

steps.headline: Place towel racks horizontally on the back of your kitchen cabinets.
steps.description: Slide lids to pots and pans into the towel racks, where they will be held in place by the center handle.

steps.headline: Install a shelf two to three feet from the ceiling.
steps.description: A high shelf, securely fastened, can hold cookbooks, platters, bowls or pitchers that you rarely use.

steps.headline: Cut a piece of pegboard to hang on a kitchen wall.
steps.description: Use metal hangers to hang pots, pans and kitchen utensils along the wall. Paint the pegboard to match your walls or your favorite color.

steps.headline: Place magnetic strips underneath kitchen cabinets.
steps.description: Suspend metal spice storage containers from them instead of a spice rack.

steps.headline: Hang door racks on the back of doors to organize office supplies, shoes or accessories.
steps.description: You can get cloth pockets or metal racks at most home or box stores.

methods.name: Saving Space in the Living Room\/Bedroom

steps.headline: Upholster the top of flat tables in your home or use removable outdoor pads.
steps.description: They will serve as extra seating.

steps.headline: Use a shelf as a bedside table or coffee table.
steps.description: A thin shelf can hold at least a light, a cup of coffee and a book.

steps.headline: Loft the beds in your bedrooms.
steps.description: Place a desk or vanity below the bed to use more vertical space.

steps.headline: Purchase corner shelves.
steps.description: They fit neatly into corners that are usually unavailable for storage.

steps.headline: Replace your bed with a model that has drawers.
steps.description: You can stuff linens and clothing inside.

steps.headline: Make sure all your sofas convert into beds.
steps.description: Pullout sofas, trundle beds and futons allow you to have guests in very small spaces.

steps.headline: Mount your TV to the wall.
steps.description: Use the space underneath for storage. Mount your computer screen to the wall to gain desk space.

text: Space-Saving Storage Replace ottoman, coffee tables and benches with models that have interior storage. Storage ottomans and benches often cost approximately the same as less functional versions of the same furniture. Place bookcases behind the sofa, next to beds and next to furniture. They can double as tables as well as storage. Turn a hallway into a storage space. Line it with hooks and hang coats, hats or even pots and pans. Install magnetic strips in the kitchen, office, shop or bedroom. Hang metallic objects like knives, office supplies, tools and jewelry on them. Hang your bike on the wall to free up your entryway. You can buy a metal wall-mount or a wooden mount that doubles as a bookshelf. Modify a cabinet to contain a pet bed or litter tray. Remove the door or install a pet door into one side of a bottom cabinet. Saving Space in the Kitchen Create vertical storage for baking sheets, cooking boards and other long, thin kitchen items. Purchase tension rods and align them vertically in rows of two between shelves. Insert the items between the rods to save drawer space. Place towel racks horizontally on the back of your kitchen cabinets. Slide lids to pots and pans into the towel racks, where they will be held in place by the center handle. Install a shelf two to three feet from the ceiling. A high shelf, securely fastened, can hold cookbooks, platters, bowls or pitchers that you rarely use. Cut a piece of pegboard to hang on a kitchen wall. Use metal hangers to hang pots, pans and kitchen utensils along the wall. Paint the pegboard to match your walls or your favorite color. Place magnetic strips underneath kitchen cabinets. Suspend metal spice storage containers from them instead of a spice rack. Hang door racks on the back of doors to organize office supplies, shoes or accessories. You can get cloth pockets or metal racks at most home or box stores. Saving Space in the Living Room\/Bedroom Upholster the top of flat tables in your home or use removable outdoor pads. They will serve as extra seating. Use a shelf as a bedside table or coffee table. A thin shelf can hold at least a light, a cup of coffee and a book. Loft the beds in your bedrooms. Place a desk or vanity below the bed to use more vertical space. Purchase corner shelves. They fit neatly into corners that are usually unavailable for storage. Replace your bed with a model that has drawers. You can stuff linens and clothing inside. Make sure all your sofas convert into beds. Pullout sofas, trundle beds and futons allow you to have guests in very small spaces. Mount your TV to the wall. Use the space underneath for storage. Mount your computer screen to the wall to gain desk space.
